sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05

And it seems just from having spoken to people, especially here in Berlin, that patience is wearing thin the longer that people who are fully vaccinated, many people already lining up in the December temperatures to go and get a booster shot as well now, are just no longer want to try and have to follow these rules because they've done everything they can to try and protect themselves and others.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05

Now Kate, you mentioned also that those who are unvaccinated now further

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And now we're going to go to Brussels for more on COVID from Shona Murray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Shona, OK, so you heard there from Kate, Germany's joining a growing number of EU countries considering mandatory vaccinations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Ursula von der Leyen says she supports it, the EU Commission chief.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A move like this, even during a health pandemic, it does bring up the question of personal freedom, does it not?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It does, but we've had this conversation, I suppose, for the past two years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Even things like lockdowns, restrictions, give up the question about personal freedoms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But, of course, as Ursula von der Leyen and others are saying, this is a crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But I'm joined now by Liam Herrick, who's the Executive Director of the Irish Council for Civil Liberties on this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Liam, talk us through the balance that needs to be weighed up in relation to the greater good of society.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We've seen obviously a disproportionate number of people taking up ICU beds who are unvaccinated versus an individual's freedom to decide not to be vaccinated?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, I think in terms of the public health effort more generally, in terms of any restrictions states are trying to implement, they need to be justified as proportionate. So they need to demonstrate that the public health benefit outweighs the imposition on people's rights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: When we come to medical treatment, there are very strong rights under the European Convention on Human Rights in terms of private life, private and family life, and bodily integrity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So the state would have a very high bar to meet to either mandate directly or indirectly a particular medical treatment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And across Europe, you've had historically very different approaches to this question.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In countries like Ireland, for example, there's a strong tradition of voluntary vaccination.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And in other Central European countries, there has been a tradition of quite commonplace to make vaccination mandatory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And that would, of course, be culturally relevant as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: What's interesting, of course, is that many of the countries that have had the most high rates of take-up of vaccination have been countries with a voluntary programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So mandatory vaccination programmes don't necessarily achieve a higher result.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But I suppose they do if, like in Austria, you're going to be charged 7,000 euro for not being vaccinated, that could be a criminal offence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And, you know, from the state's point of view, this isn't about imposing something on someone. It's about saying the rest of society is suffering because people won't get vaccinated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We've seen in hospitals in Ireland, people not being able to get lung transplant because the ICUs were filled. And so where does, I suppose, the social contract and the greater good of society impinge on the individual's rights? Well, I think the starting point is to appreciate how severe a measure it is to mandate a particular form of treatment because of how important we value privacy and particularly with regard to medical treatment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So the World Health Organisation has been very clear that mandatory vaccination laws or policies must be a measure of last resort.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So it's incumbent on the state to exhaust all other measures, first of all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That includes other measures to encourage vaccination on a voluntary basis, which have been very successful in many countries, and also needs to be in the round of all of the other public health tools available to a state.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So in many countries, there's been an underinvestment in other measures, such as ventilation, contact tracing, testing and so on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And I think the state would have to demonstrate that it exhausted all of these measures to their maximum potential before it could justify resorting towards a mandatory vaccination policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I think we'll have some member states trying to say that they did and others finding that that hasn't been the case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But Liam Herrick, thanks very much for joining us.

sentences.sentence: Mariam Mehta, the big tech giant formerly known as Facebook, has now released its monthly adversarial threat report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This is where it details information about fake accounts and networks that it has removed from its platforms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: from its platforms. In November, they said this included a number of Chinese accounts who had been posting deliberate disinformation about COVID-19 while posing as a fake Swiss biologist. It also included some French and Italian accounts that had been harassing journalists, doctors and elected professionals. But something else that Meta also focused on was deliberate inauthentic activity relating to the border between Poland and Belarus. For weeks now hundreds of migrants have been trapped at the EU's external frontier amid a political standoff and Meta says it now has evidence that fake accounts from both of these countries have been stoking tensions. In a report Meta said that it had identified around 50 fake accounts and profiles on both Facebook and Instagram, all from Belarus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: These accounts, they said, had posed as activists and journalists criticizing Warsaw and also sharing fake allegations that Polish border guards had violated migrants' rights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It said that all of these accounts were linked to the Belarusian State Security Committee, the KGB, and that some of them had even used artificial intelligence to generate fake photos for their profiles.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: These accounts were swiftly removed from Facebook and Instagram for violating their policies, the KGB yet to comment on the matter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But at the same time, Mehta said it had also removed a number of accounts based in Poland that had been posing as migrants, sharing made-up stories about how difficult it had been for them to enter the European Union, as well as some content related to neo-Nazi activity in Poland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Although Meta said there was no evidence of any state involvement, all of these accounts, they said, were based in Poland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So Marianne, this latest report just shows how, as we have seen throughout the broader crisis, both individuals in Poland and Belarus have been resorting to inauthentic online activity to try and stoke tensions at the EU's external border.
